description: Installed it, all went well during install, won't launch or do anything. If there is something else required to run it, that should be listed in the description, not left for the user to guess.

OCRFeeder claims to be offer a wide range of tasks for processing .pdf files into other more malleable formats. I installed with the hope of finding a simple, easy-to-use program that would convert a large .pdf file into a large searchable .pdf file. Unfortunately, I found a complex, hard-to-use program that failed to perform that task in even an adequate fashion.

The installation within Ubuntu Software seemed to go well. Next I clicked on the program icon and found, as noted elsewhere, that it failed to run. I ran it from the terminal by typing "ocrfeeder" and it opened. Using it by looking at the menus and commands was not immediately obvious. What is "recognition?" I went to the help files. Unfortunately, I found the instructions vague and confusing; for example, I can "Select" certain areas, but it is not clear when or why. Do I select all areas before Recognition, or just those that I want to edit afterwards? Even after using it for some time. I am not sure. I forged ahead with my limited knowledge and intent to at least give it a try.

I started by trying to process a large .pdf file that consisted of primarily text and only very simple graphics. I found that the Recognition process is fairly slow -- about 15 seconds a page. I also found that invariably it simply quit after about 60 pages. The program provides no error message or information on why this is.

I decided to give it a chance with something much smaller and chose an two-page document on constructing habitats for solitary bees and other native pollinators. I ran the Recognition process, which seemed to go well, and then tried to export in .odt, ."scratch" .pdf, searchable .pdf, and plain text. In no case did OCRFeeder recognize and convert images and text accurately. It did best on the text file; there the textual portions of the original were transcribed well but it had problems with text within images. The searchable .pdf produced an accurate reproduction of the original that was virtually unsearchable; for example, a search on "pollinators" returned no results, despite it being in the document many times, and a search of "bee" found only a fraction of the actual occurrences. In addition, the locations highlighted in the document are not the same as the locations of the words.

Both the "scratch" .pdf and .odt files resulted in gross distortions of textual elements, such as ramping font size up to 299 points, and separating textual portions into blocks that frequently overlapped each other. It was possible, with some work, to make a document that was at least usable, but I quickly realized that simply retyping the original would probably be easier and faster.

And so, I am left with no good reason to use OCRFeeder. I will delete it and continue my search for a simple, etc. program. I recommend you do the same.

As "dude" states it does not launch from the menu option in software or activities.
Key in to a terminal "ocrfeeder" {without quotes) and it does then launch into a Graphical interface. The keyboard shortcut opens a standard Gnome help which explains how it may be used. 

I used this to import a PDF file and extract the text from that. It worked satisfactorily. I have not yet tried its other features.
summary: Will run from a terminal and opens in a GUI with Help available

description: Crashes at launching
I agree with Onwer. On ubuntu 18.04 LTS simply not working, even launched from terminal.

When overwriting ocrf - damages target file
When trying to export to ODT - error occurs if non-ASCII character
etc.
Won't start. I uninstalled it.

I couldn't get it to work from the menu launcher, so I used the terminal (ocrfeeder) as noted in another review. Using the menus in the program, scanning .jpg files of screenshots was very slow and I eventually canceled it. Getting them to show in the project window was simple though, and highlighting the area to scan and recognize worked very well and was fast. Playing around with it got very good results for me in being able to get accurate text out of .jpg files.

It need to be started from terminal $ocrfeeder. 

The tool does what it is supposed to do.

The tool uses tesseract ocr library so any issues identifying text I think needs to be directed to that.
There are trainers available, however, do not expect mirracles. 

It is recommended to take high quality photos and then touch up to a black and white (2 colour) picture. If you notice any areas that represent shadows, clean that out or take a better lighted photo. I had issues with "@" characters.

The OCR engine settings is a bit over my head at the moment but you can play around with that too.
Can give no opinion of this app as it will not boot at all. I have deleted it from my Notebook!
doesn't run at all under ermine
summary: doesn't run at all under ermine

description: On looking for a simple OCR program, I tried this one, installed it, and it worked out of the box without the need to do anything with parameters or so, for a PDF which a not so great image.
It doesnt launch from the menu, just from terminal. This is a good tool, but needs to fix the launching problem

The reviews made me a bit curious. So I installed the program. It worked from the terminal. I did not bother to solve the menu link bug. It would be nice if the bug was mentioned in the description. However the printer/scanner that I use is an older model. All the scan applications had errors because of the driver. Therefore the quality of the English test was good enough for my purpose. It has some features other programs do not have. Acquiring a scan directly results in a crash, but as I mentioned these problems stem from the driver problem. The OCR function works and that was the most important thing for now.

l
ösung: OCRfeeder runs only with terminal on Ubuntu 18.04 (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/ocrfeeder/issues/1)

direkt Start über: /usr/bin/ocrfeeder
summary: OCRfeeder Startet unter Ubuntu Studio 19.04 nicht

description: /usr/bin/ocrfeeder, dann startet es....

Das Programm startet nach der Änderung der Datei.
mit einem Editor mit Rootrechten in der Datei /usr/share/applications/ocrfeeder.desktop in der drittletzten Zeile das Suffix des Starters
 -i %f  löschen.

Mit der Voreinstellung funktioniert die Texterkennung (über Tesseract) nicht. 
Abhilfe: Im Menu Werkzeuge/OCR Anwendungen öffen; Tesseract auswählen; Bearbeiten klicken, dann bei Argumente der Anwendung den voreingestellten Text ändern in:
$IMAGE $FILE -l eng -psm 3 > /dev/null 2> /dev/null; cat $FILE.txt; rm $FILE $FILE.txt
Ansonsten arbeitet die Software komfortabel und gut – bei mir mit .jpg und .tif-Dateien. 
Die Rezensionen/Tipps zum Starten müssen allerdings auch beachtet werden.
ocrfeeder öffnet sich nicht

Meldet euch als Root an # Editor eurer Wahl . . Bsp Nano, Vim .! Term auf . Tippt "Editor eurer Wahl" /usr/share/applications/ocrfeeder.desktop löscht in der Zeile Exec=ocrfeeder ,nur das "-i %f " hinweg. Speichern . OCR Feeder normal Starten über Desktop. Have Fun
